147834659.review:
EXCELENTE PARA UNIR A LA FAMILIA
Soy un padre de 50 años, probablemente una de las personas más viejas que juegan este juego. Soy padre soltero de mi hijo, que ahora tiene 14 años. Mi hijo recientemente descargó Poly Bridge 2 y en menos de una semana, ya había jugado durante más de 20 horas. Esto fue terrible para mí, ya que ya era bastante difícil para mí pasar tiempo con mi hijo, ya que él siempre sale con sus amigos o simplemente mira videos en Tiktok. Así que decidí crear una cuenta de Steam y comprar este juego para ver si podía jugar junto a él. Cargué el juego, hice el tutorial pero estaba atascado en lo que se suponía que debías hacer. Le pedí ayuda a mi hijo y organizó un juego para que yo me uniera. Me encantó porque era el mejor momento que había pasado con mi hijo desde que mi esposa había muerto. Desde entonces, este juego ha acercado a mi hijo y a mí nuevamente y ahora también pasamos tiempo juntos fuera de la casa. Este juego me recordó que hay diversión en todo, y nos ha traído tanto a mí como a mi hijo muchos recuerdos felices.

144267256.review: Muy buena secuela. Al principio pensé que este juego era exactamente igual que la primera entrega, pero la verdad es que presenta suficiente innovación, sin pasar a ser revolucionario. La innovación más notable son por supuesto los resortes, además de los dos tipos de caminos (normal y de gran durabilidad). Me pude terminar los 5 primeros mundos sin demasiada dificultad, pero el mundo 6 es donde realmente el juego prueba tus habilidades de ingeniería (y tu paciencia). Casi todos los niveles requieren de mucha creatividad y de soluciones mecánicas específicas, tanto así que, por ejemplo, tuve que buscar en Wikipedia cómo hacer mecanismos que se muevan en línea recta. El juego pasa a ser desde un simulador de puentes a ser una especie de juego de diseño mecánico, ya que hay etapas que no te dan ni caminos y hay que mover todo con actuadores. La física se nota que es muy mejorada respecto de la entrega anterior, ya que se comporta de manera mucho más consistente. Todavía hay un poco de micro-ajuste para que funcionen los puentes, especialmente para pasarlos bajo presupuesto. La música cumple su cometido, es relajante pero nada ultra-memorable. Lo que más destaco es la increíble sensación de satisfacción al terminar un puente difícil.

141019524.review:
I read a lot of reviews when deciding whether to get Poly Bridge 1, 2, or 3. I went with 2 because it sounded like it had better and more consistent physics than 1, and it was cheaper and possibly more challenging than 3. 

So far, I'm very happy with my choice. Poly Bridge 2 is extremely fun. When I fail, the results are gloriously hilarious, and when I succeed, I'm happy because it took creativity and often multiple attempts to get there. There's no getting stuck on a level, because you can always skip to any level you like at any time. Some of the concepts are better explained than others (notably, there is a tutorial for hydraulics but no explanation at all when introducing springs). Also, some of the levels allow you to build a bridge that looks like it was built by a sane person under some kind of regulatory body, and others require you to build something ridiculous that would never be legal in any civilized country. You will have the opportunity to flip ambulances upside down, send cars flying over wide gaps, and build contraptions that strategically smash themselves into a million pieces but get the car where it needs to go. But hey, if that's not your jam, there are also a ton of levels that like I mentioned, don't require criminal insanity. 

10/10 would recommend.

It's a puzzle game that has a lot of room for creative "alternative" solutions.  The challenge mode gives an interesting twist to existing puzzles allowing you to ramp up the difficulty if you want.  The physics can be a bit janky at times (why did creating an inactive split joint change the path of that car?!?) but that's generally not an issue for general game play.  

Overall, a generally pleasing combination of logic, pixel tweaking, and smashing things into other things just for the fun of it. Certainly worth trying if you like puzzles and out of the box thinking.

134539407.review:
I could wish for a bit more focus on actual bridge-building levels and fewer goofy stunt levels like jumps and the like, but otherwise this is a fun bridge-building physics puzzle game.

Physics feel pretty good for bridge building, even if they're actually quite far off from what you'd think would be the most intuitive video game version of real bridge mechanics, even 2-D-ified. For example, I believe all of the mass in a bridge is concentrated in the nodes, and set based on what materials are coming into that node. This gives a significant disadvantage to more intricate truss structures, as they have a lot more nodes. It also feels kind of odd that adding, say, a wood beam between a pair of nodes that already have wood beams doesn't actually add any mass. It also means long spans of material are lighter, proportionally, than short ones, since they actually weigh the exact same amount (so spanning a gap with a small, tight truss is very heavy, while spanning it with the fewest pieces possible is very light).

My biggest complaint, although I don't know of any way to solve it, as it's kind of inherent to the genre, is that inevitably, the kinds of levels you enjoy and are good at, you'll blow through very quickly, and barely even remember... while the kinds of levels you suck at and/or dislike, you'll spend the vast majority of your time in the game beating your head against (tweaking ramps by single pixels in criss-cross jump/stunt nonsense... *shudders*).

Still, overall, a fun bridge builder that pretty much sets the industry standard for controls, feel, level design, and elements (hydraulics, springs, rope, cables, etc).

130130522.review:
[h1] The best bridge-builder out there. [/h1]

There are plenty of copies of this type of game, but Poly Bridge is the best I have come across. PB2 builds off of its predecessor nicely to create a pleasant puzzle experience - think sudoku on a sunday afternoon. The mechanics are refined, QoL is 10/10 (key shortcuts, easy to navigate), and there are custom levels once you finish the main game - you can even make some yourself. [spoiler] Between the numerous worlds and the challenge world you unlock after completing every world under budget and unbreaking, you probably won't ever [i] need [/i] custom levels. [/spoiler] Each level is only as challenging as it needs to be, but you can set your own goals to make it harder. The game has numerous mechanics that it introduces gradually and all of them are simple, yet interesting, and refined. Like PB1, PB2 is very pretty and has a nice soundtrack.

TL;DR
Honestly, unlike most games, I can't think of anything bad to say about this game. Its mechanics aren't over-the-top, but they don't need to be. If you're looking for hyper-realism, look elsewhere. PB2 knows what it is - a simple-yet-fun bridge building puzzle game.

130014439.review:
Personally I do enjoy this game and while this game certainly does have its ups and downs, I am not here to praise or criticize this game. I am here to offer a phenomenal 4 Cheese Ravioli recipe!

Here are the ingredients you will need!

Ravioli Dough: 2 cups all-purpose flour, 1 pinch salt, 1 teaspoon olive oil, 2 eggs, 1 1/2 tablespoons water.

Ravioli Filling: 1 (8 ounce) container ricotta cheese, 1 (4 ounce) package cream cheese, softened, 1/2 cup shredded mozzarella cheese, 1/2 cup provolone cheese, shredded, 1 egg, 1 1/2 teaspoons dried parsley.

Pesto-Alfredo Cream Sauce: 2 tablespoons olive oil, 2 cloves garlic, crushed, 3 tablespoons prepared basil pesto sauce, 2 cups heavy cream, 1/4 cup grated Parmesan cheese, 1 (24 ounce) jar marinara sauce.


1. Mound the flour and salt together on a work surface and form a well. Beat the teaspoon of olive oil, 2 eggs, and water in a bowl. Pour half the egg mixture into the well. Begin mixing the egg with the flour with one hand; use your other hand to keep the flour mound steady. Add the remaining egg mixture and knead to form a dough.

2. Knead the dough until smooth, 8 to 10 minutes; add more flour if the dough is too sticky. Form the dough into a ball and wrap tightly with plastic. Refrigerate for 1 hour.

3. While the dough is resting, prepare the ravioli filling. Combine the ricotta cheese, cream cheese, mozzarella cheese, provolone cheese, egg, and parsley and mix well. Set the filling aside.

4. Heat 2 tablespoons of olive oil in a skillet over medium heat. Add the crushed garlic and pesto sauce and cook for one minute. Pour in the heavy cream, raise the heat to high, and bring the sauce to a boil. Reduce the heat and simmer for 5 minutes. Add the Parmesan cheese and stir until the cheese melts. Remove the pan from the heat and keep warm.

5. Meanwhile, in a separate saucepan, warm the marinara sauce over medium-low heat.

6. Preheat an oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Beat the egg with the tablespoon of water to make the egg wash.

7. Roll out the pasta dough into thin sheets no thicker than a nickel. To assemble the ravioli, brush the egg wash over a sheet of pasta. Drop the filling mixture on the dough by teaspoonfuls about one inch apart. Cover the filling with the top sheet of pasta, pressing out the air from around each portion of filling. Press firmly around the filling to seal. Cut into individual ravioli with a knife or pizza cutter. Seal the edges.

8. Fill a large pot with lightly salted water and bring to a rolling boil over high heat. Stir in the ravioli, and return to a boil. Cook uncovered, stirring occasionally, until the ravioli float to the top and the filling is hot, 4 to 8 minutes. Drain well.

9. Grease a baking sheet. Place the cooked ravioli on the sheet pan and bake in the preheated oven until brown, about 4 minutes.

10. To serve the ravioli, divide them among four warmed serving bowls. Drizzle the marinara sauce over the ravioli and then top with the cream sauce.

123758077.review:
Meh. A little better than Polybridge 1 but still suffers from the difficulty spike of 1. 

Most of the levels after the first world are quite hard. This isn't bad but the difficulty spike is too rapid. 

The game is quite repetitive with no new concepts after the first world. All the gameplay mechanics have been introduced by then and the only thing to keep the player going is to make the levels more and more challenging and complex. 

This is ok for a hardcore player but honestly I just want to sit down, make few bridges and chill. 

I actually have more fun watching youtube videos on how players have solved the levels than playing it. 

The devs really needed to have a more gradual difficulty escalation (similar to angry birds) and more slowly introduce game play mechanics rather than everything given to you in the first world and then the only thing to look forward to is frustratingly hard levels. 

I only played the first world and half of the second before uninstalling it. 

Not for me but I'm glad others like it.

118479139.review:
Poly Bridge 2 is a game about building bridges and testing your patience.  Haven't beaten it yet, but I did put a solid 27 hours in and got all but the last level, a few workshop levels, and a few challenge levels before giving up.  Difficulty is medium to How Do You DO THIS!? hard.  Used a keyboard and mouse to play.  Good game for kids and engineers/architects.  

I got this game after playing Poly Bridge 1.  The physics in 2 feel more solid to me.  There are also custom level designs and SPRINGS!  

The music is nice bits of guitar that helps you focus and is generally enjoyable. 

There are a ton of bridges to build, and each level is harder than the next.  I did well until the last level, then I hit a wall because too many thinkybits were needed and I ran out halfway into the level before that.  Then there are the Challenge level versions of everything, which are even harder.  

I feel there should've been a tutorial on springs.  There are other tutorials, but later on the springs are very important and it took lots of creativity to figure out how to use them.  

If you get stuck, there is a gallery to show you how other people did it.  This was EXTREMELY helpful whenever I got legitimately stuck.  

There is genuine fist pumpery when you succeed at a really hard bridge that you've been stuck on for days.  

There is also genuine rage to be felt when everything you do doesn't work and then, when it does, you change one little n'th of a thing and everything comes tumbling down around you like a deck of cards.  

A Sandbox mode has been added.  Make your own bridges!



All in all, I deeply enjoyed Poly Bridge 2.   Well worth my money to get both the game and soundtrack, and a real joy to play as far as I did.  Hope to install it in the future when I really badly need to build bridges so I can officially beat it.  Until then, enjoy!

113102666.review: This game has become the quintessential bridge building game. The gameplay is great and varied, with plenty of challenges presented in the regular levels as well as the "challenge levels" section where previous levels need to be re-completed with new, harsher requirements. The graphics are simplistic but refined, your viewpoint can be set and forgotten or dynamically changed while the bridge traversal simulation is playing. Replays are saved for your creations and other peoples' solutions are viewable after completing a level. The game runs smoothly on low specs, and beautifully on higher-end rigs. The devs carved out a reasonable scope for their game, and absolutely crushed it. If you're looking for a simple but perfectly executed bridge building game, this is it.

112076345.review:
A relaxing way to tease your brain, Polybridge 2 pits you against physics and a series of challenging spans. Some interesting real life bridge techniques are viable here, arches, tension, and normal truss architecture is modeled in an enjoyable way.

The leaderboards are nice, but a lot of the top scores are wack solutions that glitch the game or just do some kind of dangling road exploit. Still, it's nice to be able to compare your solutions to other working ones and sometimes even pick up new techniques.

If you like engineering, and need to take a break from the more traditional games, Polybridge 2 will happily fill in a few hours of your time as you work through the challenges.

108617756.review: Very fun even if you have very little skill

108564523.review: It's a good game, but only if you have pre-existing knowledge. The game provides almost no feedback on why certain configurations do or don't work. There's no visible math or tools as far as I can tell. Either the bridge works or it doesn't. I was hoping to learn some stuff about bridge engineering from this game, and I probably will, but it'll mostly take trial and error and my own guesswork to understand. Even if you look at other people's builds it is unlikely you will glean much insight as you cannot look at how EXACTLY they made their bridge; you can only guess by watching a replay of it in action. Given replays aren't visible in game until you've built your bridge successfully for the first time I don't really understand why I cannot look at the specific build of their bridge and learn from it. The in game ui also lacks an easy to understand 'stress' function. You won't know if your bridge has overly stressed parts until you hit play and then you have to wait through the whole simulation, try to take note of what parts of the bridge fail [it'll only show you the first break on retry] then hit retry. Still, fun enough game. Probably more fun if I had even the slightest clue how bridges work.

107865519.review:
Poly Bridge 2 is a game about building bridges to let different vehicles reach their flags.

Well, at least that's what it starts like.

Some levels boil down to finding just the right angle to send your car in a specific direction, or adjusting a spring to make sure the bridge shifts to the left a few pixels. These levels are not fun. Most of them are not like that and are fun though!
My favourite levels are the ones that use hydraulics.

Later levels demand that you learn just how Poly Bridge 2 works in order to beat them. The 6th world and the challenge version of the 5th world in particular will kick your arse. For me, I entered some sort of trance and after 100 hours (that's 100 hours in 2 weeks) I came out on the other side, all achievements in hand, feeling nothing but relief. I mean, it was fun, but at the same time... you know?

Ahh, you like puzzle/engineering games and also hate yourself? Welcome brother. You know, I'm not sure these are bridges anymore. Oh this? This is uhh... I'm not sure what this is actually, but it gets the car across!! Huh? Triangles? Ah triangles, yes triangles good, squares bad. Steel? Throw that in the trash my dude, wood muscles is where it's at! Overbudget?! I haven't even done half the bridge yet!! Wait, bridge? This... looks nothing like a bridge.

THIS IS NOT A BRIDGE.

105833053.review:
Awesome game.  Not a lay back and chill game, it requires you to use your brain.  I see a lot of reviews saying that it's unplayable for the average person or non-engineer but I disagree.  You'll need to turn on your engineer brain if you want to achieve anything above top 30-50%, but most of the levels are fudgeable until the 3rd or 4th world.  And if it's too hard turn on sandbox mode or unlimited budget and build something cool to get the cars across while you learn about about suspension and compression.  Every failure teaches you something about bridge construction and progress you through the game.

What I like most about this game is something that was touched on in a top comment.  The dynamic physics engine allows for micro manipulations without drastically changing the outcome.  What I mean by this is, since every simulation is exactly the same as long as nothing is touched... you can make minor tweaks to the bridge which (usually) only results in a minor change to the car's path/trajectory/speed etc.  That's how I feel like I can learn from this game rather than guess the exact perfect solution.  I find that when I use my maximum brain power in finding a solution, all of my scores end up within the same 2-3% on the leaderboard. Its an IQ test.

Not sure how often this goes on sale but for how detailed and pleasant it looks for a bridge building game I think it is entirely worth the $15.
